The structure of the English law of homicide is rather strange.

Although there are two offences,  murder and manslaughter,  the latter includes two distinct varieties:  ‘ voluntary ’ manslaughter ( killings which would be murder butfor the existence of defined extenuating circumstances );  and ‘ involuntary ’ manslaughter ( killings for which there is no need to prove any awareness of the risk of death being caused,  but for which there is thought to be sufficient fault to justify criminal liability ).
